reviews.review_msg: Nice guy and sweet to students. This is a writing course based on the philosophical class topics. He is a very harsh grader for the papers but gives A LOT of feedback which is handy. Didn't love the mandatory class discussions, I would always be chosen to talk about my posts. Very passionate about Asian studies so it's a big focus in class.

I thought Paul Crowe was an okay prof until the lecture got switched to online and he started replying to students' email in a rude and unrefined attitude. He is for sure a picky marker, your marks can be heavily taken off if one of your sentences isn't written correctly.

I had to satisfied by W requirement, and HUM101W was my only choice that fitted my schedule. I was extremely confused at first because I had no background in Humanities, but Paul was a great professor. You have to read a lot to understand, and it is writing intensive. However if you read enough, you will understand most things he teaches.

Hum 101 was a great class, Dr. Crowe really took the time to meet and chat about papers and key concepts regarding assignments. He was a very fair professor and his course allowed for a great introduction to humanities.

Professor Crowe is an amazing teacher. One of the best I have encountered. He is extremely devoted and spends time to ensure that the course is of the highest quality. He gives so much feedback even though it takes him forever because he cares. He is a genuine real teacher who gets you to think rather than memorize.

This class seems pretty easy at the beginning. Although when it comes time to quizzes it is impossible to prepare for them or be ready for them. The general ideas are not tested but very specific details that seem irrelevant are tested. I would not recommend this course. It is definitely not a GPA booster. It is all about philosophy.

The class was easy and well-rounded for an entry-level humanities course teaches both traditional and modern philosophy. This class is safe to take because you can dive into any part of humanities you prefer in the essays. All three difficulty points are for the way he marks essays (sometimes he could have gone easier).
Professor Crowe is outstanding. Very passionate toward the subjects he teaches. Would deffinitely take a course with him. He tries to make lectures engaging and interesting.

Aspires to break from standard system models of university, encouraging back and forth between students and professor. He enjoys the idea of meeting for lunch with as much of the class as possible to encourage this form of learning. Fair marker, challenges you without sinking you.

I did not find that visiting him during his office hours helped my grade, either for the essay or the exam. The material on the quizzes WASN'T self-evident - though I attempted to read the texts thoroughly. The final exam was even worse than the quizzes (for the same reason).. I will go out of my way to not take a class with this teacher again.
Excellent prof., enjoys out of the box thinking. Was able to explain a foreign religion, in a foreing language with ease.

Great course, he took us on field trips to temples and brought in speakers! Professor Crowe is kind, enthusiastic, extremely knowledgable, wise, funny -- a truly incredible teacher, unlike so many dull and uninspiring professors. Take his courses!

Paul is genuinely nice guy who is approachable and passionate about what he teaches.  That being said, he knows SO much about Chinese texts, philosophy & history that he can tend to talk complicatedly about a lot of things that we beginners know nothing about.    It helps if you are extremely interested in the subject to begin with.

A genuinely nice, caring guy. The material he was teaching was very complex, but he did his best to get it across. He also gave you lots of room on your term paper, so that helped. Easy to talk to. The most passionate prof I've ever had as well. We had field trips! I'd take him again in a second.
great prof, one of the nicest guys I've ever met. He teaches incredibly complex material but works VERY hard to try to get his students to understand it. I'd take him again.
a very interesting class. he really wants all of the students to understand, but don't worry, the stuff that is really confusing is not testable.

Extremely soft spoken prof who is approachable and very helpful. He really cares about his students' understanding of the material. Although the course material was ext. difficult, he patiently tried to explain in a matter in which we could understand. Great prof!

he's a great prof! and i have serious trouble understanding how there can be people that think otherwise..PLEASE trust me, take one of his courses, and you'll witness first hand lectures that are comprehensive, informative, engaging, and blah blah, a whole bunch of other flattering adjectives
this prof should really ease up on his marking! Nice guy, but expects too much!
if u attended to his class, you should be fine!
He's in love with Confucian philosophy. Only take a course by him if it's SUPPOSED to be about eastern philosophy, because no matter what he teaches, it always comes back to Confucius and Mencius.

Too focused on historical aspects, glosses over a lot of the actual 'cultural' parts, such as the effect of XYZ on Chinese culture.  Classes started off mostly relevant, starting about the third week, he's been so carried away by philosophy/religion he misses every other topic on his outline.
cares about the subject matter and trying to get students interested.

The class is "intro to chinese culture" but he's morphed it into "intro to confucian philosophy." He uses LOTS of circular arguments and repeats himself over and over and over and over. Bring a pillow to class, cause desks are hard.
